title: St. Patrick's Cathedral to be ready for pope’s visit
text:
St. Patrick's Cathedral to be ready for pope’s visit 
IF YOU GO 
Catholic sites 
Pope Francis will stop at these historic sites during his visit: 
• Washington : St. Matthew’s Cathedral, 1725 Rhode Island Ave. N.W.; stmatthewscathedral.org . Site of President Kennedy’s funeral Mass. 
• New York: St. Patrick’s Cathedral, 5th Avenue near Rockefeller Center, saintpatrickscathedral.org . Seat of the New York Archdiocese. 
• Philadelphia : Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul, 18th Street and Benjamin Franklin Parkway, cathedralphila.org . Knotted Grotto outside dedicated to Mary, Undoer of Knots. Travel Mary Altaffer | ASSOCIATED PRESS This recent photograph shows the newly renovated facade of St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York. 
NEW YORK — A three-year restoration project at St. Patrick’s Cathedral, the seat of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and one of the country’s best-known churches, is coming to an end just in time for a late September visit from Pope Francis. 
Officials are steadfast in saying the work will be done in time. 
The project was officially announced on St. Patrick’s Day 2012 and began soon after. It was a huge undertaking — the entire exterior was covered in scaffolding, all the way to the top of the two 330-foot-tall spires, and it was washed clean of decades of dirt. Inside, workers cleaned and repaired the 3,700 individual panels in 75 stained-glass windows and restored the 9,200-pound bronze entrance doors. 
St. Patrick’s held its first Mass in 1879 and became a national landmark in 1976. At $175 million, the restoration was the most extensive since the 1940s. 
Some thoughts from people who worked on the project: Not your everyday worksite 
One tricky aspect: The cathedral stayed open to the public the entire time. Work was done around daily Masses and while 5 million visitors a year passed through. 
“It would be a constant dance as we were moving around,” said Eileen McCarthy, a project manager from Structure Tone. 
“For the most part, everything was done during the day while it was occupied, while tourists and guests and visitors were coming through, so that was always a concern; you’re working in a living, breathing environment.” 
Construction workers had to learn how to use their “inside voices” but were also given a chance to interact with the public. 
“People will stop and ask” about the work, she said. “It’s very cool, you can explain a little bit of what’s going on.” Moving moments 
The renovation also led to some unexpected moments of grace. McCarthy remembers a time in late 2013 when she and painters were up on scaffolding above the central part of the cathedral, hidden from view . 
“All of a sudden, a capella, was a young woman’s voice, singing Ave Maria ,” she said. “All of us just froze, we stopped in our tracks.” Perfect timing 
The project seemed to have the luck of the Irish. Jeff Keeley, a foreman for the scaffolding company, said it was “very uneventful.” There were no safety incidents, and clear skies and good weather were on hand when they needed it. 
Pope Francis is scheduled to be at St. Patrick’s on Thursday for evening prayers. 
Keeley said workers were excited to find out their efforts would be seen by the head of the church. 
“Sometimes you do things, and no one really cares,” he said. “When the pope comes, hopefully he will care, right?”
